Problem:
Consider a complex-valued function \( z(t) \) governed by the equation \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \), where \( \omega \) is a real constant, representing angular frequency. An integral transformation defined by \( T(z) = \int_{0}^t e^{-i\omega s}z(s) \, ds \) is applied to study its properties over time \( t \).

If \( T(z) \) is applied to \( z(t) \) initially at t = 0 and allowed to evolve according to \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \) without further intervention, will \( z(T) \) at a later time T be affected by this transformation?
Explanation: The transformation \( T(z) \) does not alter the evolution of \( z(t) \); it computes an integral which depends on the history of \( z(s) \) but does not influence the future trajectory governed by \( \dot{z} = i\omega z \), thus \( z(T) \) will evolve as if \( T(z) \) was not applied.
